No real spoilers, but perhaps some hope will be spoiled/grounded in reality.

I found myself in awe at times while playing this game, it really does some amazing things. I was thinking things like.... more games need to do this... holy crap this is cool....wow, game of the year ideas... and other impressed-sounding taglines... etc

Great story setup, graphics are nice and the overall atmosphere etc is great. This game had me so excited at some points, but I guess somewhere at the back of my mind was the low pricetag and the assumption it was all going to end too soon, and I guess for me it did. I don't mean 'it was short, and Í am not happy with short games'. Thats not me. Short is good if its complete. A game could be 100 hours long and be too short if the story needed 150 to play out. What I mean is it just sorta stops right as you are really getting into it.

Also - I really disliked the block puzzles sections. Really disliked being forced to do them, and really disliked doing them. It just felt like filler for a game that knew it was already too short. Like the short kid wearing platform shoes and not thinking anyone would notice, but I noticed. I give this section 2 thumbs down. Really detracted from the immersion and the story. I get that they werer part of the story, but they didnt need to be part of the game narrative itself.

I would hands down recommend this game for the 13 dollars worth that you get, they have done some very cool things here; but would also warn that you will wish you had spent 20, maybe 40, if it meant it had the rest of the story fleshed out or more juicy information. It feels like I just bought a cool sci-fi book from a second hand bookstore only to find out the last 3 chapters are missing and someone put a post-it note saying 'its all good' and a picture of fireworks there to replace it. Play it, maybe what I am trying to say will make sense, maybe it wont. Perhaps you will race here after playing to write yet another 100% positive review, we need about 50000 more of those. I just feel people might want to know the downs, even if it is only 13 dollars.

The trouble I have is it just felt like they ran out of money or ideas and without spoiling anything, I was left feeling unsatisfied in a big way. For a game to reach so many highs to fall flat on its face was for the biggest twist of all.

Its hard to be this blown away by something and at the same time so utterly disapppointed.
THEY DID SO MANY COOL THINGS THOUGH. There I said it. So cool on so many levels. But....come on... what happened?

I give this 1 thumb up 1 thumb down.

reviewText:
Cradle is an interesting game along the lines of Gone Home or Dear Esther - you are unfolding a story as you progress. You will solve some not overly complicated puzzles to advance the story.

The atmosphere in the game world is hauntingly beautiful.  The lighting, music, dialogue - everything is perfectly honed to create a sense of eerie sadness and mystery.  I personally loved the slower pace of the game, it was fun for me to try to uncover information as to what has happened in this world.

The mini games were ok, a little tedious and you can skip them if you fail with no repercussions on the storyline.

Keen Stalker fans will recognize some similar themes here, experiments on conciousness and contaminated zones, you can see the loose influence the Stalker franchise has had here, having some ex-Stalker devs working on it.

The ending may seem abrupt but if you pay attention to the dialogue throughout, and the clues scattered around your home, it makes more sense than if you skip through a lot of the details.

This game was right up my street but if you prefer more action orientated games it may not be for you.

reviewText:
Let me start by saying that it really pains me to rate this game down, and that if I could I would have given this game a neutral rating. But in the end I have to choose a side, and I’m sorry but I have to go with negative, let me explain why.

Cradle is a first person exploration and adventure game, I would probably describe it as a first person point and click, because the gameplay basically consists of clicking at things, picking things up, using things on other things, and rarely combining items. You have a limited inventory, for brief storage of key items, and it serves its purpose nicely. Going along the story you’ll have to play some minigames, which felt very out of place, and basically consisted of one simple and easy game repeated four times. These minigames were reasonably enjoyable, but felt like they were there merely as filler content in a short game. I feel like the gameplay is one of the games weak sides, of which it has a couple, but it wasn’t bad, just not good.

As for the story, I was pretty disappointed. The game takes place in a very well built world, but doesn’t utilize much of it, and delivers a story which was short and ended abruptly, without giving answers to many of the questions asked. I mean it literally ended with the sentence “I will explain everything” *credits roll*. *SPOILERS* At first it start out with a classic trope: you play a guy that has lost his memories, ‘who am I?’ But it slowly changes direction into something about terrorism, but not, and then it turns into ‘who is this girl I have sitting on my counter’. I felt like the story went all over the place, without really explaining anything. Don’t get me wrong I enjoy stories where you have to think for yourself, but this felt like the developers started a story they couldn’t quite finish, and therefore ended it prematurely.

Technically the game wasn’t good either, as it didn’t run well on my pc (you can check my specs on my profile, but I use a GTX 780), I did have the graphical settings maxed out though, but even then the game didn’t look fantastic, with subpar texture and model quality, and a problem with aliasing. The game was definitely playable, but the framerate would often drop to 30 FPS. On the other hand the whole gameworld was handled in a single world, and therefore there was no loading screens when moving from area to area, there would however be loading screens when starting a minigame, or going to a new chapter, and the loading time wasn’t brilliant.

I liked the sound design, and the soundtrack is good. I am listening to it as I am writing this. Cradle does feature voice acting, but the main characters acting is wooden, and not great. Ida’s voices are pretty good, and Tabaha’s are not as good, but good enough.

Now, the art is this games absolute strong point, and definitely what sold me the game in the first place. I have actually followed this game for years, because the art intrigued from the first moment. And I must say, the best reason to buy this game, would be as a piece of art, because boy is the designs beautiful. Set in a futuristic Mongolian wasteland, the interesting stuff is pretty sparse, but the designs more than makes up for it. The little yurt where you start the game, uses very beautiful Mongolian designs, and I am particularly a fan of the boots you’ll find in a chest later in the game. When venturing out of the yurt, you will come find a giant dome, which apparently is an entertainment park. This dome is more futuristic, but at the same time run down and overgrown. I will put some screenshots on my profile.

Overall I decided that I can’t recommend the game to the price, as it simply falls short as a game. You might be interested in it though as first person exploration games aren’t particularly common. If you are interested in the art however, this has some of the best I have seen in a long time, and I might play through the game once more just to look at stuff again. I bought the deluxe edition, but the art book isn’t worth the extra, so only get the deluxe if you want the soundtrack, which incidentally is pretty good.

TLDR; this game is a piece of art, don’t buy it if you are looking for interesting gameplay or a good story, you will be disappointed. If I could frame this game and hang it on the wall, that would be the perfect use for this game, and as a piece of art, it is worth it in my opinion.

Intriguing and relaxing game with a wonderful soundtrack - a true indie gem! Developed by Flying Cafe for Semianimals (a studio created by former developers of STALKER: Call of Pripyat, Heroes of Might and Magic 5 and Allods Online), Cradle is an immersive, atmospheric adventure game set in a somewhat post-apocalyptic Mongolia.

You wake up in 2076 in a yurt in the middle of a steppe and cannot remember a thing. There is a broken mechanical girl in your room, and a huge, abandoned dome nearby.  You can roam the world freely, interact with objects and physics, read tons of documents that help you understand what happened (think Gone Home and The Vanishing of Ethan Carter).

There are a lot or Orwellian things going on here, there is also a mysterious virus called 'desperatoxin' and some strange, smoke-like cratures. Your task is to repair your companion, explore the dome and learn what happened to the world and human society.

reviewText:
A somewhat fresh and unique take on a horrific robot future that I personally can't wait for in real life.

But back to the game. This is another one of those slightly ambiguous get as much out of the story as you put into it kinda of narrative experiences. So saying anything specific is full on spoiler territory and honestly one of the best features about this game is the way its told. The way the world feels real and actually lived in.

Let me start by saying I absolutely hate reading things in games. Not in real life but in games it always feels contrived, forced as if they could think of no other way of communicating the idea. It does not feel that way in Cradle.

In Cradle, there are newspaper articles that are stuck to the insides of cabinets, buried under clothes or old cooking utensils. And you can read all of them. The strange part was, I actually wanted to. It gives you just enough information each time that you want to click on everything to try to piece together one more string or on going theory as to the nature of the world as it is.

Your character has amnesia.. this is never really explained which is slightly disappointing not only because its cliche and a narrative explanation would be great but because everything else in the world is explained. The only reason I could come up with for the character to have amnesia is a conceit for why he needs to ask and explore so many things. A story telling mechanic. Now at this point you're probably aware you speak to robots in the game. I won't reveal the nature of them in game but their eyes are actual video of a real humans. AND to top it off this is actually explained narratively within the games lore and it totally fits. Not only does it add incredible interesting visuals to the world its actually there for a reason.

Now for the parts I didn't care for, There is a mini game in which you collect blocks and throw them into a tube of light to collect them. Its fine. You do this multiple times however and one of them is a little much. Its more frustrating than not. However I did find through this you can skip the mini games. I only skipped the one but some part of me is sad I didn't rise to the occasion and prevail. I thought about it later and realized that's not what I came here for anyways and not being frustrated was much more of a desired outcome. I wanted to know more about the world. As I stated previously this mini games existence is not just fodder for your fingers to increase play through time. It is also explained within the lore.

I will state however the ending does not give all the answers and leaves you to interpret details and is arguably better for leaving those details for you to ponder afterward.

reviewText:
I cannot understand, regardless of this game's flaws, how anyone could not recommend this, unless for some reason they didn't like all of the fantastic things about it (and if someone exists who did not, I'd love to pick their brain to find out why - it's fun exploring what I don't understand).

I wanted more time in this world. I wanted more of this world. I wanted more of the characters. Even with the limited amount of places to go, the world felt big in a way that games rarely present. There is a lot of space around you. Most of it is empty, much like the real location it's based on, but that's a beautiful and haunting feature of the landscape, not a problem.

It does feel that the ending was rushed (though I'm not pronouncing final judgment there - I'm waiting for an epiphany that will make it all come together and make it retroactively more satisfying) and I feel a bit teased with everything else.

Those minigames that some people talk about? I had fun with them. Yes, at a couple of points, I wanted to shove my keyboard through my screen, but with determination, I finished them and wound up enjoying them overall. Particularly in two of them, where I realized that slowing down and remaining calm was the best way to beat them. The other two had a different dynamic, the one that nearly turned my monitor into a keyboard-holder, that really tested my patience. But they were short and there weren't that many of them. I think that was important. If the story relied on them too much, I could have seen them as more of an impediment.

In any case, if the game looks interesting to you and you're considering it, I very emphatically tell you to go for it. It's really an experience I don't think you should miss.

reviewText:
First of all it has to be said that Cradle is stunningly beautiful and has some fantastic ideas going for it. The world feels unbeleivably fleshed out and detailed for such a short game, and it's practically certain that even the most dedicated completionist won't find all of those little details in a single play through. Normally that would be a good thing, but not so with Cradle. It was a serious disappointment for me.

The thing is, there's so much information crammed into the world that it becomes overwhelming, and when the ending comes, it comes suddenly and without explanation. The main path through the game reveals so little that it's entirely incomprehesible without a tremendous amount of tedious sifting through newspaper snippets, posters, letters and other bits and bobs. I get the feeling that there's a fantastic story hidden in there somewhere, but discovering it is a punishing experience. You'll want to know more for sure - but you're not going to enjoy trying to figure it out.

So what about the mechanics of this game? Well... There are two parts. One is searching for a multitude of hidden objects in a world full of clutter (find the TV remote simulator, anyone?) and the other is an oddly out of place mini game involving collecting cubes in a neon virtual reality world. It does tie into the storyline, in a tenuous way, but doesn't really add much to the whole.

Perhaps Cradle is meant for people who feel that working (really) hard for a story makes it all the more rewarding, but to me it felt more like a game which simply never came together properly. It's confusing, lacks polish in its mechanics and doesn't give itself enough time to go anywhere. That's a serious shame, because this is a world which deserves recognition for it's beauty, depth and originality.

reviewText: This is a very short but highly thought-provoking game.  It doesn't hold your hand the way most modern games do (thankfully), but it's not very challenging either.  Most of its puzzles are logical and/or intuitive and generally fairly forgiving.  The virtual minigames were the worst part only because they were tedious.  The art is a little scattered:  the interior of the yurt (where you live) is done very realistically, but the landscape outside (particularly the sky) looks like a fantasy painting, which is a little jarring.  It was like the artists couldn't decide whether they wanted to be realistic or fantastical.  People with OCD might also have difficulties with the fact that if you pick something up, in many cases it's nearly impossible to put it neatly back where it was (eventually, it will fix itself, though).\n\nWhat I really liked about this game, though, were its story, setting, and characters.  You're dropped into this world with no memory of who you are or where you are, so it's very easy to get into the role of the character you're playing, because it allows you to ask basic questions you need to ask to understand things without it being out of character.  If you want just the general gist of things, you'll have to ask lots of questions as you move through the story.  To really understand what's going on, though, you have to take your time and read even seemingly inconsequential things left lying around.  If you don't, when you get to the end, you'll probably just be confused and/or feeling like the ending was abrupt.  On the other hand, if you've paid attention and put enough clues together as you go along, the ending is both absolutely amazing and poetic.

reviewText:
A Paladin’s Review: Cradle. Contains An Ugly, Poisonous Sponger.Genre: First Person Single Player Narrative Exploration Game.
Developed & Published by: Flying Cafe for Semianimals
Platform: Windows and Linux.
Business Model: Single Purchase + Optional Extras DLC
Copy Purchased by Myself Read the full & unabridged review A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]

Overall Gameplay Thoughts
It’s a first-person “open-world” narratively driven game. It’s not really a walking simulator as you can go off the beaten path but it’s not really an open world either for reasons I’ll explain later. But suffice to say, the lack of side quests or additional areas to explore make me question the open world label on this game. Set in a futuristic world of what appears to be Earth, the player doesn't know who he is or what's going on. It’s a four hour experience which considering everything it has to offer, is probably more content than I wanted. The player is tasked with solving the mystery of who they are, what this mysterious robot is in their yurt and what’s going on.

Gameplay Examination
The player starts out in a small yurt-like building that, upon leaving it, reveals a large open plain with a colorful building nearby and some sort of track system. I’m going to start off by saying that I don't agree with Cradle being called an open world game. I mean, you have this big open level that has all of the space in all of this clearly designed content to be an open world game. But when you actually experience the game, you realize it’s nothing more than moving back and forth between a couple of buildings. Sure there are little bits of lore strewn throughout the level and little collectibles to find but you’re not encouraged to locate them (and I didn’t even know that they existed until I looked at the achievements). Exploring this world is problematic. Even when I did, all I found was the same bland landscape with a few minor curiosities here and there. I did go to the edge of the map and I found the invisible wall. Which strangely has you collapsing from being out of breath. I find it curious that they did more than just create an invisible barrier, they actually had a special effect and labored breathing to go along with it. I doubt that many players would go that far. Not when the slow pace of walking/running and lack of incentive really doesn’t encourage the player to go off the beaten path.

Narrative Discussion (Spoilers)
After completing Cradle’s tutorial your character wakes up in a yurt. Who the player is and what's going is unknown due to amnesia. Looking around, you can see a robotic vase, a small kitchen, bed and other living items. The game directs you to create some sort of meal for someone and so you go about doing it. Upon leaving the Yurt, you can take a look around at the open plain you find yourself in the middle of. After doing some fairly uninteresting tasks, you’ll eventually be able to turn on the Robotic vase and the plot starts to move along. However, she too has amnesia. This is where the game’s narrative really starts to lose me. It’s one thing for the main character to not know what’s going on but for the second and seemingly only other character to have amnesia is just a little too convenient. Especially when this character will continually drip feed information relevant to who these two people are and the world around them. As she’s remembering these things, we discover that a plague has been threatening to wipe out the human race. But humans transferred their consciousnesses to robotic bodies until a cure can be found. So, the duo try to salvage parts while looking for answers until she loses power and the ultimate final conclusion.

PC Settings & Optimization
Settings include a graphics quality slider (I don’t approve), a reasonable selection of resolution options, fullscreen on/off (no borderless windowed), V-sync on/off, field of view slider from 50 to 80, textures low/med/high and antialiasing off to 8x. I can’t find out what kind of AA the game is using. Anisotropic Filtering is missing as well as view distance and a bunch of other graphical settings I expect in similar titles of this genre. Sound and music volume sliders are here but there is no voice slider. Keys can’t be rebound. Xbox controller is supported. Steam controller support isn’t official but it works.

The optimization for this game is extremely poor. Maintaining a stable 1080p, 60FPS is impossible even after setting everything to low. The graphics, while colorful, do not justify how poorly this game performs. Outside of the major characters, a lot of the world and foliage is very low fidelity. There’s also a number of graphical glitches including clipping and pop-in. It also doesn’t help that a lot of textures, especially in the main yurt, look like glued-on textures. It gets particularly bad if the game is trying to show the amusement park. Audio design is simply ok but not that engaging. For a big open lonely world there isn’t a lot of atmosphere to keep you invested as you travel around. Music is decent if forgettable.

Final Thoughts
Ultimately, I'm not surprised that I'm not happy with Cradle. I already had suspicions about the game even during its development process that this was a troubled project and the final product shows those issues quite clearly. In it we have an open world title that would be far better suited to a more focused narrative experience. There’s clearly a desire to talk about classism and DNA/eugenics but lacking the subtlety to pull it off gracefully. It’s poorly paced, poorly optimized and ends too abruptly for me to excuse. Exploration is only encouraged through achievements and that’s not good enough. What few game mechanics there are, are nothing more than busy work to pass the time. It’s a game that’s conflicted from the ground up and everything suffers as a result. Had Cradle gone on for more than the 3-4 hour runtime, I definitely wouldn’t have completed it. So, I can’t recommend Cradle.

reviewText:
Fantastic and breathtaking, if you're willing to deal with some slight unpolish.


Spoiler Free: This is a game best enjoyed slowly. Nothing about this game is fast paced. The story and exposition is delivered piecemeal, there is a fair bit of dialogue, a lot of reading, and even the run speed isn't particularly speedy. If you rush to the finish line you will not have a great time as I did. Which leads to the prime particuliarity of this game: the exposition is limited, the story will not hold your hand and it is largely up to the player to put everything together.

That isn't to say there aren't characters who will sit you down and explain things to you. That does happen. However whatever information you get from them is augmented by the dozens and dozens of notes, article clippings, phamplets and posters found in the Main Character's small home. Some of the keys you need to put the story together can only be found by combing through all the papers. The dialogue will only get you so far, and at one point the exposition stops. You will have everything you need if you're diligent (it isn't that hard, just reading) to add it all up, but the game isn't going to explain itself in the end. You'll only have theories. I feel pretty good that I'm right about mine which is enough to leave me satisfied, but that may not be everyone's cup of tea. Otherwise the world building and lore is top notch.

As for the actual gameplay, well. There are some mini games that are very platforming/jumping heavy and those aren't fantastic. There is a reason for those segments to exist story-wise, but they are the weakest parts of the game. They are thankfully slippable if you fail them once. I only managed to complete two, and they were not fun enough for me to want to retry the ones I failed. But that's OK, no penalties for failing and skipping. No combat, but there might be one or two instances where you need to throw sticks at things. You can keep some sticks in your inventory which is a tad clunky. The objects in the world will reset themselves after each storybeat/autosave and that was a blessing since I got a tad carried away with the physics and threw around everything.

There were occasional bugs, one of which required a fresh install to fix, and another to restart the game. Controller support technically exists but it's pretty poor.

The sounds and style are beautiful. I found myself honestly touched or upset at certain points in the story. The main character's voice acting is flat/monotone by design.

My recommendation is to play this game in a few chunks. I liked being able to chew on the story bits over night and let them ferment. It isn't a long game, and savoring the story and crafting theories helped build up the enjoyment. It gives you a compelling mystery, and I will play it again to experience it all from a new perspective. I still haven't found all the information and lore there is to find! Absolutely play this game (just know what you're getting into), it is one of my favourite scifi stories.

A decent game with some unfortunate design decisions.

The cube minigames are optional, but you have to play them through to continue.  If you fail, you have the choice of continuing anyhow, apparently.  When I failed the first one, I just quit the game before I was given this option.  I found out about the option from the forums here on Steam.  And then I beat all 4 of them without failing again, making it a moot point.  I don't find the cube games fun at all, just a time-waster.

The rest of the game is more like a sparsely-population hidden object game than a point-and-click adventure.  There are quite a few things to look at and move that are useless, and a few things here and there, usually hidden or halfway hidden, that are actually useful.  Unfortunately, if you find something early, you can't do any better than just remembering where it is.

Your inventory is limited, and if you quit and load your game, everything is back where it was originally, unless it has to do with something that was changed permanently in a previous quest.

It's also possible to lose important items, forcing you to quit and load a game in order to be able to find them again.

Finally, the story is...  illogical.  A lot of it makes no sense at all, and if you're a technical person you could very well rage against the tings they try to pass off as logical.

In the end, though, I enjoyed the game overall, so I'm recommending it.  I've focused on the bad points here, but the game is beautiful, the voice acting is pretty good, and it's fun to explore and solve even simple puzzles in such an environment.

reviewText:
You are alone in a yurt in the middle of the Mongolian steppe with no companion other than a broken android chick with a flower vase for a lower body. Cradle sure is an intriguing elevator pitch! It’s a shame the actual experience is short and yet somehow still feels padded and just doesn’t sustain this initial sense of mystery.

But let’s talk about the yurt first. It has one of the greatest sense of place I’ve seen in a videogame. It’s rickety thing worthy of the Middle Ages, but it holds a contemporary TV/DVD player, an early 20th century kitchen and futuristic doodads including the aforementioned android. It’s also credible as a lived in place: filled with family photos and documents to read, a Buddhist shrine, children’s toys, etc. It’s worth it tearing the place top to bottom to see what mysteries it has to reveal and it has quite a few.

Stepping out of the yurt for the first time is equally impressive. Hills lazily stretch over the horizon. A lone line of elevated hover train pylons leaves to the imagination the outside world it could connect to. The enormousness and remoteness of the steppe are well represented, but there is almost nothing to interact with out there, as can be expected. The only other place to explore is a derelict amusement park. The puzzles in Cradle should be mostly familiar to anyone who has played first person point-and-click adventure games. The park, however, adds a virtual reality Minecraft cube-digging minigame, as improbable and inopportune as that may sound. The game even tries to find a good reason why there would be block puzzles in the middle of the steppe. The explanation is about twice as implausible as the story reason why Quiet has to run around half naked in Metal Gear Solid V.

The story itself is just weird. I’ve wondered what kind of conversation some dude in the steppe would have with a robot chick. It turns out the answer is “a lot of dry exposition”. Cradle’s approach to sci-fi is to assault the player with a shotgun blast of gobbledygook. I won’t spoil it here, but I find it’s a lot of concepts crammed in a 4-5 hour game, culminating in a abrupt and quite odd ending. Some of it is compelling, but I have to admit it mostly didn’t do it for me.

I didn’t terribly like Cradle, but I admire it’s ramshackle originality. It’s something that it somehow seems only Eastern Europe can produce (Pathologic and Stalker come to mind). Unlike many indies custom-made to cater to hipster sensibilities, Cradle has a real sense of authorship. Considering this and the lack of grading options, I would give Cradle a thumbs up, although it is not raised very high.

Cradle is a sort of dystopian/post-apocalyptic/sci-fi themed game. It's incredibly atmospheric and immersive, but the world you see in the trailer is pretty much all you'll see in-game. Cradle's true value lies in the experience of piecing together the past with your attractive female companion through scattered texts and story progression. So don't go into the game expecting intense puzzles or gameplay. Both of them tend to be rather simple. Don't expect this game to last more than 4-8 hours, either.

But for what it's worth, the atmosphere and story absolutely sucked me in, and I wish there was more.

Was it worth $13? I think so. Although the repetitive, chore-like gameplay far outweighed the brilliant story progression and atmosphere in terms of hours, I don't regret buying this game. It was a good way to spend a weekend, and I'll be thinking about it for quite a while.

reviewText:
I actually regret giving this a steam 'thumbs down' because I'm not really sure I'd rate this as a bad game. It's weird. Steam lacks an 'it's ok but....' option or even a middle of the road 'not good or bad' option. In the end, I weighed up what I enjoyed with what I didn't enjoy and felt the negatives were too pressing to for me to give this a flat out recommendation.

HOWEVER - I will say I did actually enjoy this game for the most part.

First off, the setting is beautiful. Set out on the empty steppes on Mongolia, it's really visually pleasing. The graphics are mostly decent with some good textures employed. The yurt in which you are based has been lovingly crafted, and really helps draw you into the world. The characters seem interesting - the robotic lady on your table is certainly interesting.

I enjoyed the open world style of the game, though it's only really open world on a technicality. It's open world as in the setting of the game is entirely accesible to you - but there's not much going on out there. In all fairness, it's in the middle of the Mongolian Steppe so I'm not sure I'd expect much to be going on out there so it's not a major point.

I liked the sounds in the game. The sounds of birds chirping, the wind blowing. This was good.

The story is fine, and actually has some depth to it. I think the game really could've done more with it but seeing as it's only a short game I guess I could give it a pass here. What we do learn of the story is rather intriguing. But this does lead me to a major negative for me - the story ended very abruptly, and at that point the ending didn't make too much sense to me. I was left scratching my head as to what happened. Without saying too much, I felt it just sort of ended and assumed we knew everything there was to know.

The optmisiation of this game was quite bad. My PC's specs are far and away above what this game recommends and I had a low frame rate for quite a lot of the game. As visually pleasing as it is, it really isn't too demanding graphically. I forced 60FPS using Radeon Settings panel which improved my FPS bit didn't fully solve the problem. This poor frame rate lead to laggy controls which made some navigating quite cumbersome and unweildy.

The game physics were kinda odd too. Once again, this may be due to the lag I described earlier, but it certainly drew me out of the game and just made it feel unweildy. Picking up objects and moving them around wasn't always smooth, and sometimes things would just get stuck. It was difficult to placet things gently on the table as if you let go of an object you just sort of drop it right in front of you - but for some reason I couldn't stand close enough to a table for my object to fall on it.

When I put all the negatives together, I guess it felt rushed, or unfinished. A definite shame, because it looked so promising, and had hints of brilliance during the game. Some of the dialogue is really quite intelligent and thought provoking.

In conclusion, this is a game which demonstrated real potential. The ideas and world building were pretty good, but I felt the execution was ultimately flawed. If I were to recommend it on it's merits, I guess it's at the very best a cautious recomendation - if you can look past shoddy optimisation, and story telling which teases so much more than it actually presents.

reviewText:
tl;dr
Good in general, short story, ok-ish controls, great design, amazing music and graphics.


Note: This review may have a bias towards sci-fi games, because sci-fi is awesome!

Story:
Like with most quest games, the story gets revealed as you play the game. You learn about the protagonist's origins and some of the characters in the game, though not everything gets revealed. I failed to learn about the dark swirls which you encounter while exploring, though I have my suspicions. Perhaps I just have to play the game again and read/listen more carefully.

Gameplay:
Overall good, though a bit sluggish for my taste. The normal walking speed seems a bit slow and you can only run with holding the left-shift key. I didnt find an autorun feature. Granted, the game world isn't huge, but it would have been nice to have. The game has no highlighting for interactable objects. Cradle features minigames that you have to play to further the storyline. Though they seem like crap on the screenshots, they're actually quite fun to do.

Design:
I wished this game was bigger and featured more quests and such. Though being a rather short game, it does leave quite an impact. The idea of the m-bodies(the android woman) with a modular design could potentially turn this game into an adventure game where you craft/scavange parts to make your own body better. I can imagine a whole new game centered around this little gem.
The world goes from morning to night time, but not over time. Every stage you complete causes the sun to locate to a new position in the sky with a new set of clouds. It's quite charming to say the least.

Dialogue:
The game has dialogue options though not always relevant. It's really just click a trigger to listen/read the conversation and then click the next trigger. I think the game is to small to make this feature stand out.

Controls:
The object interaction may need some improvement. For example, I have the genometer(a scanner) and I want to try it on a flower(not knowing what I was doing at the time). Instead of the game telling me I can't use it on an item, or nothing happening at all, the tool just drops out of my hand. This is because left mouse-button makes you drop the item. I would prefer it to do nothing instead. If you're in the open with lots of grass, or even in the yurt(the tent) objects just seem to disappear. Just like in real life where your remote teleports to an alternate dimension when you leave it on the couch unattented. I accidentally threw a glass on the floor and had to look for it for 20 minutes untill I found it under the workbench. And yes, the damn glass was a quest item.. Good thing, when you reload the game, all items are back in their original spot, but I was late in figuring that out.

Additionally, it's actually rather hard to put something down properly. You pick up a lighter from the table and it's really hard to put it back on the table like a normal human being. You're holding the item really close to your body and dropping it means it falls on your toes. There's no way to extend the object's distance from the player to put it somewhere. It kind of frustrated me when I took the salt from a shelf and tried to put it back on the shelf. There's no way to do it properly so I had to throw it using the right-mouse button instead.

Audio:
Good in general. Voices are clear, interaction sounds are well defined. No annoying background sounds or anything done too well, if you know what I mean. Voice acting seems ok, though something seems odd about the protagonist's voice. It's like he got bored throughout the game. Just play the game, or watch a playthrough to see what I mean. Nevertheless, not annoying in any way.

Graphics:
Amazing! Just pick the android woman apart and look inside. It's all really well designed, modelled and textured. High quality textures and attention to fine details. One thing though, the leaves on the trees and the grass in the outdoors are bilboards, like in the old Duke games and the like. Not bad per se, it just seems they did that to cut on the rendering engine. It's already a GPU intensive game, and it isn't even Crisis.

Price:
So the game cost me 13 euro's and I found it to be a bit much considdering the story being a bit on the short end. I think 10 euro's would have been better. If you feel like spending those extra few bucks, then go for it. This game is a gem.

Conclusion:
Finished the game in about 6 hours, and that includes just me derping around occasionally. Would play again, just for the music and the minigames..

I hope this review has been useful. Cheers. (>*3*)>

reviewText:
This review was written for FREEDOM Community Gaming Collective[freedomcgc.com].
I wake up in what seems like a strange hut. It’s adorned with all sorts of decorations that feel Central Asian. At first glance, it’s filled with familiar items you would expect to see in this setting such as a firewood stove, but on closer inspection, I see things straight out of the future. Strange contraptions, digitized flowers, and most peculiar of all, a mechanical woman is sitting on the table. Her upper body seems normal, but she’s been altered from the waist down to act as some sort of vase for the digitized flowers. She is deactivated. The big red button beckons me to press it. She starts to twitch randomly, then settles down for a brief moment and looks straight at me before she slouches over and shuts down once again. There’s a calendar by the door. It’s the year 2076 and I’m in Mongolia. This isn’t a hut, it’s a yurt. I open the door and step outside. At first I see a small fenced yard beyond which the horizon stretches out to uncover rolling hills among the steppes. I get the feeling that this is going to be one hell of a journey of discovery.

Cradle is a first-person adventure game by Ukrainian developer Flying Cafe for Semianimals. It weaves a fascinating, intriguing and wholly original science fiction story set in a world in which a cataclysmic event has made people unable to reproduce. In a desperate attempt to preserve humanity until a permanent solution is found, people transfer their souls and consciousness into mechanical bodies. You will discover many details about this complex, layered story as you freely inspect and interact with pretty much any item you find in the world such as magazines, journals, pictures and so on. You will also be able to interact with a couple of characters who will provide information and tasks which will move the story along. The writing is strong throughout and while it provides plenty of exposition regarding the world and what has been happening on a global scale, it failed to provide a meaningful emotional and personal connection between the two main characters. The fact that the voice acting for the playable character is rather stiff and detached created an even wider gulf in their relationship. However, I have to point out that the voice acting for the two non-playable characters is very convincing.

The true star of the game is its game world. While it is structured as an open world, it’s relatively small and mostly takes place in and around the yurt and a nearby deteriorated entertainment park. I didn’t found this to be a negative at all, I felt this focus created a true bond between the player and the surroundings. This strong sense of place is further heightened by the magnificent art style. There aren’t a whole lot of landmarks in the game, but each one is superbly detailed and everything just feels cohesive which is odd considering that it is a mixture of Central Asian, Eastern European (visible in the tram design, for example) and cyberpunk influences. I deeply appreciated the fact that the developers were able to create a world in which the old Mongolian tradition of eagle hunting mixes with cutting edge concepts such as transferring consciousness onto artificial carriers in a way that makes perfect sense. The subdued yet poignant soundtrack also added to the atmosphere immensely. I simply cannot overstate the impact of the game world on the enjoyment of the game.

Regarding the gameplay, Cradle will mostly task you to find certain objects and use them in the appropriate way. For example, in the very beginning, the player is tasked to make breakfast. That means you’ll have to light the firewood stove, put the pot on it and then find and use all the necessary ingredients. Even though the game is a bit too obtuse at times (at one point, I spent around 15 minutes looking for a TV remote in the yurt which I found to be completely unnecessary and flat-out bad design), it is mostly rather generous with its hints and most items are where it makes sense for them to be. You have limited inventory slots at your disposal which is fine because you don’t need to collect and carry around everything you see and find. The puzzles are situational and you will only need certain items at specific points in time. Another big gameplay element are the mini-games you’ll have to do in the run-down entertainment park. These are arguably the weakest parts of the game. Basically, each time you’re placed a large room filled with cubes and you have to throw cubes of a certain color into some sort of digital stream in the center of the room. Your progress is impeded by digital enemies which will destroy cubes and/or block access to the stream. The whole ordeal feels tedious and laborious and it feels as if it was thrown in there just to provide some gameplay. Happily, you have the option to skip these segments if you happen to fail them, but you still have to endure the whole thing until you either succeed or fail.

My biggest and most serious complaint comes from the purely technical side. It’s not the game’s performance, it runs pretty well even on more modest systems, it’s the limited options and lack of key remapping. Just like a lot of warm-blooded PC gamers, the first thing I do when I start up a game is go to the settings menu. When I clicked on Cradle’s settings menu, it opened a single window with rather limited graphics options. There’s the V-sync, AA, texture and just a few other options including a 1-10 quality slider. Needless to say, it’s not really clear at all what this slider affects. However, while having limited graphics options is certainly not great, it’s not really such a big deal. On the other hand, I was appalled once I realized I cannot remap input controls in any way. The game uses a WASD control scheme which I’m sure a lot of people use and they’re fine with it, but the fact of the matter is that a lot of people do not use that scheme and it is simply inexcusable to release a PC game without the ability to remap keys. Cradle also does not have gamepad support, so the developers are quite literally saying that it’s their way or the highway. Being forced to play the game with a control scheme I do not prefer definitely had an impact on my overall enjoyment of the game and was the direct cause of frustration in certain segments of the game.

Cradle is a remarkable yet flawed game and I cannot escape the feeling that it could have been truly exceptional. It is held back by certain design and storytelling issues as well as an ending that is far too ambiguous for its own good, and it fails to provide all the necessary options for the player, but it shines due to its beautiful game world, intriguing theme and characters, and strong atmosphere. Despite its flaws, it is a game that should definitely be experienced by anyone who enjoys exploring fantastic worlds woven with a fresh science fiction story.

7 OUT OF 10 (VERY GOOD)

reviewText:
I thoroughly enjoyed Cradle.  For me, it's pros outweigh its quirky cons.  I bought the game because I tend to like science fiction and games that address cybernetics, artificial intelligence, singularity and transhumanist type concepts.  However, this story turned out to be very surreal and deals mostly with some really imaginative metaphyscis.  It feels like a myth transpiring against a sci-fi backdrop, which is really very charming.

The game pulled me in, with the very first room.  You start out in this wonderful little yurt, and it's obvious that the designers lovingly crafted the whole interior.  There is so much detail the place could be real.  The protagonist has no idea what is happening, which leaves you sifting through the contents of the dwelling, to try to make sense of things.  From there, you encounter several point and click adventure style puzzles and a few arcade mini-game sequences.  As you progress, the dialog helps make more sense of things.  But, if you want the ending to make sense, you have to thoroughly explore and read everything.  It's completely possible to finish the game without having any idea what the ending sequence is about, because all the reading that clears it up is completely optional.

The graphics are great, and really contribute to the immersive feel of the game.  The sound track is sparse, but beautiful in my opinion.  The voice acting is pretty solid, with 2 out of 3 primary speaking parts delivered quite well. Controls are simple and well suited to the genre.

The cons.  Running on Ubuntu 15, on a laptop with i7 and Windows Iris, I've had a few stability issues.  This has been the main drawback to the game. Also, the arcade mini games feel a bit clunky and agravating at times and the point and click style puzzles can be a bit on the easy side.  As wonderful and immsersive as the yurt is, it turns out there isn't really much more.  While practically every square inch of the place is interactive, there are few other locations, and everything else is very sparsely populated with interactive elements. Basically, the setting is just so immersive and interesting, that it leaves you wishing there was more.

reviewText:
Developed by a small indie studio with a limited budget, Cradle nonetheless successfully features both a huge world of the future and meditative, contemplative gameplay focused on exploration of a small but rich to details fragment of it. With its rich narrative and details this game resembles a good sci-fi book; however, Cradle never tries to put the all answers in front of you, so you'll have to do some research and exploration to uncover every detail!

Unlike other story-based quests, Cradle also features some platformer/puzzle mini-games. Many people are complaining about them, and actually I was surprised to see these complaints. The mini-games are actually well-designed, fun to play and also they fit the story.  Only if you're playing only slow-paced quests and never played platformers or puzzle games like Portal, they will probably appear tricky or boring to you.

This game isn't perfect to everyone, but it is certainly unique and beautiful. It has its own atmosphere, incredible story, stunning graphics and contemplative experience - that's why I recommend it.

Sadly, I can't even comment on the game itself, but I'm writing this review to advise others to stay away from the title.

Cradle is riddled with a number of bugs that can make it nearly unplayable unless you happen to have the perfect set of circumstances for it.

You will find yourself staring at the undersides of tables and having to jump just to read the first note or interact with nearly anything. Again, the developers seem to be doing nothing to fix this problem besides saying that they are working on it.

So these two bugs combined to make my first few minutes of the game frustrating and absolutely intollerable for a game relying solely on environment immersement. Coupled that with the fact that the last patch to the game came in Early October, I had to return it. I do not expect the issues to be fixed any time soon and that truely saddens me. I wanted to like this game so much, but the bugs make it unplayable.

reviewText:
This game feels like a lot of wasted potential to me. The themes and story seem intriguing, if flawed in several details (antibiotics had no effect on the virus? you don't say.). The world is gorgeous. But the technical execution leaves much to be desired.

The puzzles required to proceed through most of the game are, to put it bluntly, sloppy. For example, very early on you must put a glass of water in a pot to heat it and cook something. I locate the faucet, I look for a glass, I find hundreds of cups in the house but of course none of them could possibly serve the purpose. I finally find the one specific glass which will function for the purpose, and you might think I could use the glass with the faucet, but that doesn't work. Perhaps I need to turn the faucet on before I pick up the glass, and use it on the running faucet? No dice. Maybe I could place the glass in the sink under the faucet, then turn it on so the water would fall inside? Well, apparently I'm not capable of holding the glass far enough away from my body to drop it in the sink, so it falls to the ground, either bounces wildly or clips through the floor, and I spend the next twenty minutes scouring the entire cluttered environment for the one specific small, transparent object I need, before restarting the whole game. As it turns out, you need to turn on the faucet before picking up the cup, then use it on a very specific tiny portion of the stream of water coming out, or you're doomed.

The basic engine used for moving around and carrying things is perhaps even less polished than the puzzle design. It starts with some kind of horrible mouse accelleration making it so that any small movement of my hand doesn't actually move my cursor at all, but a slightly larger movement will cause me to spin around entirely, but I can adjust to that. Then there's the character movement, which is clumsy at best, but workable as long as you don't need to do anything precisely or quickly. Picking items up means that you will never be able to put them down in a way other than dumping them on the floor and hoping for the best or throwing them off into the distance, but that's tricky to program and a lot of AAA games struggle with it. But what I really take issue with is that any time you're carrying a (probably vital) item in your hand, rather than your (arbitrarily and pointlessly tiny) inventory, it's not even locked to the position/orientation of your character, just constantly tugged in the direction of the cursor. Which might not be noticable while you're walking slowly and facing one direction, but the moment you try to run or turn around too fast, there's a significant chance that the item will fly out of your grip. Often never to be seen again, forcing you to re-load.

And finally, several times over the course of the game, the story will be put on hold and all the wonderful characters and environments set aside in order for you to struggle through the mandatory minigame" which consists of a poorly explained combination of platforming

reviewText:
As always I'm slightly on the edge should I recommend this. I loved the world, the writing. the aesthetics and the athmosphere. I actually enjoyed the openness of the ending witch seems to be complaint for many. But it's slightly on the short side and I see how this could have been one of the definitive gaming experience of my adult life but it just falls slightly flat... If there just had been some side quests to let us settle more into the world, maybe even third place to visit beside the yurt and dome. Maybe more interaction between the girl and our main character not directly involving the main storyline.

Other gripe I've got is the decition to have player character have a voice. That feels a bit uncanny in a first person game, especially as the english voice actor was slightly on the stiff side. This tought I could overcome as the writing of the dialog is solid, as is the case with all the other writing done for this game. I also got a weird vegetanion sprite missalligment where leaves didn't touch the trunks of trees and the flowers didn't connect to any of the traws coming from the ground. Also the lack of FOV-slider and key-rebinding in the options menu, is to be mention. Altought it didn't bother me as I don't get motion sick and play with WASD.

Then on to the positive side as aesthetics and graphics of this game are amazing. The world seems vibrant, but slighly washed out giving a feeling of mixture of reality and aquarelle painting. The visual desing of the android bodies is just something that will blow you away altought there's just two of them. They really look like something real humans have transferred their consciousness to. Something they live in and have personalised. The video eyes gives them amazing character and liveliness altought no other part of their face moves. The world feel lived in and seems to well match the slowly progressing disaster that is revealed have happen to humanity.

Continuing with the positives music and the sound desing are also solid. You feel like you are on the mongolian steppe as the wind blows trought the trees and birds shirp in the air. Music is just spot on and is eary in the right way. Even in the pavillions the slightly cheerier music gives this overall wibe of something beeing slightly off.

After those positives I've got one more gripe. There actually feels to be a slight pacing issue in the game. The main mechanic around exploring is not in any way timed or rushed. As for the opposition narrative driven in conversations with the girl drives a sense of urgency fairly early on (for spoiler reasons I will not reveal). I think this could have been fixed with more 'casual' conversations with the girl and the third character, and so giving the main conversational narrative a space to breathe same way the exploration has. Othervice the story and writing as mentioned is great. All the clippings are well written, characters make sense and even the lameish amnesia startingpoint is made to work trought what you find in the world and how you want to interpret them.

At the end I'd recommend this, but with a disclaimer. This game is mostly about the aesthetics, world, story and the athmosphere. It is somewhat lacking in the mechanics department having very limited and scripted interactions with the world. I would even compare it to 'Dear Esther' as a virtual installation altought with lots more interaction. In both narrative is given to you in pieces for you to interpret and the ending gives similar feeling of who or what was our pov-character in the end and what actually happenned.

Despite there is lack of replay value with my other gripes, this game will most likely end up there with the rare games that I will revisit from time to time for that 'reading that familiar book wibe' and if I could find new angle on interpreting it.

reviewText:
Thoughts after my first playthrough:

First off, this is a very short campaign. The story itself takes place between three locations within very close proximity. All told, if you play it straight through it'll take only three or four hours at most.

But that's only if you do nothing but the quests while ignoring everything else, of which there is lots.

If you want to get the most out of the game, be prepared for a lot of reading. Every scrap of paper down to the newspaper that lines kitchen drawers holds bits of plot. Fortunately, it's very engaging text! While reading these is not technically necessary to finish the game, you are going to be extremely confused if you don't.

That said, what gameplay there is maintained my interest and left me wanting more up until the credits rolled.

Speaking of the ending: If you are someone who needs your endings to neatly wrap up the plot threads in a a nice neat package, this game is probably not for you. Or if you do play it, definitely seek out every bit of reading material you possibly can and, to lead into my final point...

...EXPLORE. EVERYTHING.

There is a vast desert out there! Once you get the mechanics down, walk away from the plot for a while and go exploring. There are things out there that you will never even get the chance to notice if you strictly follow the plot.

All in all, it's exactly what I hoped it would be: A fascinating story with interesting game mechanics wrapped in an expansive world that you can get lost in for as long as you want.

Plus it's only $16 for the deluxe edition with the kickarse soundtrack!

This is one of my favorite games that I have played in a few years.  The past 2 or 3 years I have begun playing many games halfway through then stopping to play another as they just don't hold my attention very well as they all seem to be lacking one or more things in favor of something else.  This game probably isn't for everyone so here are the major reasons that I enjoyed this game so much were:

1) The way tasks worked like many older games there aren't arrows pointing to all of your objectives on the top of your screen or on a minimap.
2) The backstory and plot were done in a way that makes sense, and you have to piece it all together from what you read, find in the enviroment, and learn from dialogue so it keeps the player more engaged rather than spoon feeding all of the story to them as they mash random buttons to victory.  This makes people like me who enjoy reading everything they can find in a game feel more rewarded.
3) The game is all about exploration there really isn't any combat (though there sort of can be if you find the laser sword).
4) The art style of the game is very well done everything in it all looks like it belongs nothing feels out of place, and there are a lot of small details that are very easy to miss.
5) Most objects in the enviroment can be interacted with in a way similar to games such as Amnesia.

The game isn't perfect but I had a lot of fun with it and would say that it was easily worth the price.  If you decide to get this game my one piece of advice would be to read everything you find, and pay attention to it even if it doesn't seem important at the time there are notes hidden all over, and they will help you make sense of the story.

reviewText:
Cradle is a SciFi story. Go into it expecting to be the character you're playing. After completing the first play-through, I believe there is a major view that the player should prepare to take, that is, the view of life/culture-shock. If you can empathize with people in a coma, who wake up after being asleep for even just 10 years, and see the confusion they're in, then I believe you'll be able to welcome this game (and it's concept) with open arms.

Now onto the game itself.

Story: Phenomenal, I've read a lot of SciFi and this story feels extremely original and compelling. You can tell almost immediately that the devs focused heavily on building this entire world to be a possible alternate future, filled with cultural, medical, and societal changes. If anything I hope they use the success of Cradle to create a series of games built from this world (it's that compelling).

Gameplay: A little rough. The game controls very simply, but asks you to find and do some rather specific things that sometimes are just a tad frustrating. It feels as though the devs didn't get many chances to playtest the game to beta-testers.

Sound: Very good, though somewhat forceful at times. The music walks the fine line between 'forcing emotion' and 'boosting emotion'. As in, there's many moments in the game where a rush of powerful music doesn't push me to feel something, but rather, allows me to be overwhelmed with that feeling. Just now I'm realizing that whole situation may play purposefully in tandem with the game's core themes.

Value: For $12, absolutely worth. It's like going to the movies and watching Interstellar with popcorn and soda. Only you can be at home and actually move at your own pace through the story (and have much cheaper popcorn and soda).

So ya, that's my takeaway. For those put-off by the ending (I'll be honest, I was pretty confused as well), please checkout the 'Ending' thread in the community hub, a lot of users there have already started piecing together the rather vague elements of the story.

reviewText:
Story/Gameplay
This game is set somewhere in Mongolia year 2076. You wake up in a hut, or Yurt, and have no memory of who you are or where you are.

The game doesn't hold your hand in the way of storytelling, you have to figure out the story all by yourself, if you have time you can find a ton of reading material in the hut about what has happened, but the main story comes from the android woman on your desk which you have to repair. The game does however hold your hand through all the tasks you are given and tells you exactly how to solve everything, though you can choose not to read these hints if you want to, so it's not so bad.

Back to the woman on your desk, the story progresses when you repair/replace a part in her and new information is revealed to you through her, because as she gains new components she remembers more things about her past. There is also another person/android which I think is an old friend, I'm not quite sure, but he reveals more information about the past in exchange for flowers (you will get it if you play it).

Now, the way you collect these new parts is quite dull, you have to play one minigame for each part, which doesn't sound bad at first until you get to the second minigame and realize it's the same one, just altered a tiny bit. The whole thing becomes tedious after a while and you find yourself trying to rush through it so you can unlock more storytelling and not play stupid minigames involving cubes. The story reveals why these minigames exists and why you get parts after completing them, and also why they are so dull, but this could easily have been changed so they all are completely different from each other and not all consisting of cubes and still fit it into the story. This is one of the two things I didn't like about the game.

The second thing is that it states that it is open world, which it is, but you only go between two places all the time, you even find a thing so you can travel between these places quicker, and they are only like 500m apart. Sure you can go explore but there is nothing to be found, it's just a big steppe or whatever it's called. I think there are some collectibles laying around but I didn't find a single one.

Where this game really shines is in its story, they have created a really good backstory and an explanation to almost everything, there is a certain four digit code I have not found the explanation to yet, hopefully it is buried somewhere in all the readable things laying around, and yes, everything is readable, every little scrap of paper laying on the floor to long news articles, and everything is relevant in one way or another. You really get the sense that this guy is living out here all by himself, making his own electricity, food, water and selling flowers to his friend which comes by once in a while with supplies in exchange.

Graphics
The graphics are what to be expected from a game in 2014. They have created an almost Borderlands type of filter, so it looks a bit cartooney or like it's drawn by hand. The skybox is a bit lacking in my opinion, the clouds do not fit in with the rest of the game so well, but I see where they are going with it, they just made it a bit too much 'hand drawn on paper'. But overall it's almost stunning how good they set the mood with the graphics alone.

Sound
The soundtrack of this game is also amazing, it really fits in with the story and setting. I never buy soundtracks for games but for this I am considering buying it, maybe.

Prize/Rating
If you buy this game for the story, not the gameplay, you will have a great experience and a huge aha" moment at the end. It's even fun to play through a second time when you know all the lore and understand everything that is being said. I played through it in a day
date: so it's not so long. It's 3€ too expensive in my opinion but still worth the money. I'm hoping for some sort of sequel
recommended: or even a prequel because the story is so rich and it would be interesting to see how other people live

reviewText:
Absolutely blew me away.

You wake up. You're lost in a strange place. Around you are scraps of paper - That's pretty much all you start out with.

It doesn't handhold, and never definitively spells things out for you. You slowly learn about the lives of a few characters, and the even stranger world they exist in. It's a game full of discovery, weirdness and feels.

It's a short game - took me about 6 and a half hours. If you wanted to rush through you can probably finish it in much less than half that; But you'd probably entirely miss what it was really about. If you want clear direction, and the thought of searching through and discovering things for youself (opening cupboards, reading newspaper scraps etc) sounds unappealling then you probably won't enjoy this game. If you like the idea of discovering things for yourself, and finding enough fragments to paint a picture of a truely alien world, then this game will definitely be the ticket.

To define it in terms of mechanics: It's essentially a point and click adventure game, where you discover clues and also progress along a story. It's also first person, so a lot of discovery involves exploring the world yourself, and picking up and moving around objects (and a simple inventory system). The actual gameplay side of the story is fairly short, but the lore side is wonderfully wide, as long as you the player choose to search it out.

The game is fairly graphically intensive (probably best played with a gtx 760 min or equiv.) and doesn't really come with many graphical settings - just a quality slider, and the ability to choose resolution and antialiasing.

There's no input configuration controls, so if you can't play with wsad you're out of luck.

All that being said I found the story pretty amazing. It definitely left me with a strong feeling. However it does not spell things out for you entirely. If you don't like piecing parts of the story together (the pieces are all there, you just to find them, and piece them together yourself) you will probably be left confused.  But if you do then you'll love this game too.

A beautiful game.

reviewText:
Absolutely blew me away.

You wake up. You're lost in a strange place. Around you are scraps of paper - That's pretty much all you start out with.

It doesn't handhold, and never definitively spells things out for you. You slowly learn about the lives of a few characters, and the even stranger world they exist in. It's a game full of discovery, weirdness and feels.

It's a short game - took me about 6 and a half hours. If you wanted to rush through you can probably finish it in much less than half that; But you'd probably entirely miss what it was really about. If you want clear direction, and the thought of searching through and discovering things for youself (opening cupboards, reading newspaper scraps etc) sounds unappealling then you probably won't enjoy this game. If you like the idea of discovering things for yourself, and finding enough fragments to paint a picture of a truely alien world, then this game will definitely be the ticket.

To define it in terms of mechanics: It's essentially a point and click adventure game, where you discover clues and also progress along a story. It's also first person, so a lot of discovery involves exploring the world yourself, and picking up and moving around objects (and a simple inventory system). The actual gameplay side of the story is fairly short, but the lore side is wonderfully wide, as long as you the player choose to search it out.

The game is fairly graphically intensive (probably best played with a gtx 760 min or equiv.) and doesn't really come with many graphical settings - just a quality slider, and the ability to choose resolution and antialiasing.

There's no input configuration controls, so if you can't play with wsad you're out of luck.

All that being said I found the story pretty amazing. It definitely left me with a strong feeling. However it does not spell things out for you entirely. If you don't like piecing parts of the story together (the pieces are all there, you just to find them, and piece them together yourself) you will probably be left confused.  But if you do then you'll love this game too.

A beautiful game.

reviewText:
There is a lot here to recommend Cradle.  The visuals, for the most part, are beautiful.  About half of the voice acting is  quality work.  The concepts and characters are compelling and can be generally identified with fairly readily.

However,
Cradle falls short.  It is so good in certain ways but...  It's like a beautiful woman who is wearing heels too tall for her.  It looks beautiful, it seems like it might even have something interesting to say, and then it takes a misstep and falls on its face.
The subgames, though explained halfway through, feel jarringly out of place until that point.  Walking through the beautiful landscape generates a certain feeling that does not mesh well with the subgames, feeling like a hacking puzzle in an FPS, a contrived challenge that is just there to act as a weak barrier for you to mill through, separating chapters, making you backtrack, and not even being unique among themselves.  I feel like the game could have easily been better without them.
The story, though a bit confusing at times, is very well told for the most part.  The little snippets of information provided by the readings and the conversations point to a fascinating world with fascinating possibilities and a future like you've never quite imagined.
And then you go back into the subgame, completely disengaging you from the storyline and presenting you with hoops you don't even have to jump through.  (I'll spoil this with no guilt.  If you fail a subgame, you can just skip it and still get the achievement.)  When you finish it and get back into the storyline, it gets even more interesting and tantalizing, a bit more of the story is revealed.  And then it goes back to the subgame.
Worst of all is the ending.  It seems like it's really building to something.  It seems like it's getting ready for the big reveal, answers for your questions.  But it isn't.  It's going to give you a halfhearted hand waved in the vague direction of the answers to your questions and then ENDS WITH A DAMNED MUSIC VIDEO.  I'm not saying everything has to be handed to the player but there basically is no third act.  It jumps clear past it to a climax without epilogue, like watching the first two LotR movies and then skipping to the big final battle from the third movie and ending once the battle is won with no more explanation.
I will say this though.  The soundtrack is beautiful.  I am still torn as to whether it's worth buying but it's definitely beautiful.
It was so good, except when it wasn't.  It could have been so much better, but it wasn't.  I'm not sorry I played it but no, I cannot recommend it.

Please read carefully, sadly steam doesn't have a mixed recommendation button so I had to pick Yes or No, for me it falls on the No end but you might still like it.

This game is a wonderful enigma. There are questions that will never be answered. The world is strange, unnatural and begs exploration. You will look through dozens of small clues to get a big clue to get access to a bigger puzzle. That said none of this is part of the game. You will be doing this on your own OUTSIDE of the actual game.

The actual game is composed of a linear go here, solve basic puzzle structure of missions with timed events that will not trigger, unlock or be completable until you have solved the previous puzzle. It is the strictest of railroads we are speaking here. Should you find a piece of a puzzle three objectives down the line you shant be allowed to solve it on pain of the game forcing you to reload because you screwed up. On top of this are several minigames where you collect cubes, one stage of which I would like to punch whoever designed it.

The real game is a weird question. What the hell is going on? One which remains completely utterly unanswered. No matter of searching, no matter of thinking and no matter how far you roam you won't find the clues required to get an actual answer. The best you will do is some vague idea of what happened and a little sprinkle of magic. The why, for what reason or how won't really be answered.

That is why I can and both can't recommend this game.

If you enjoy thinking about a game long after it's done, going back and rereading certain messages and documents to make a bit more sense of it all, knowing you will never get an actual answer this is a game for you. The athmosphere is perfectly unsettling. The world so strange you will want to know more about it.

However be warned that the game really is nothing more than a few dozen one quite obvious solution puzzles intersperced with a few block collecting minigames, that don't change except for a completely ridiculous difficulty spike on the third minigame. You will NOT get a satisfying conclusion to this story as even the meaning of what you did cannot be answered despite you sort of being able to puzzle together what you did. The ending is abrupt, following an edge of your seat moment, that peters out into an ending song that was quite nice, but a complete anticlimax because and I REALLY have to stress this. There is no way of knowing WHY what you did was important in ANY way!

So if you are like me and demand a game to be both mechanically sound and intersting with a clear method of answering the important questions you will feel let down in the end. If you simply want to play this game for the mystery it is a solid recommendation. Be warned though, it stays a mystery.

Perhaps answers will be found in the sequel, Cradle 2: The Craddeling, but I don't play games to play the sequel so I can make sense of the first one.

reviewText:
The game reminds me of Dear Esther, or The Old City. Or even to some extent, a game like FNAF. What I mean is that the game is interesting and mysterious, but to really understand what's going on you have to be prepared to read into the game a lot. Read and listen to every piece of article, text and conversation. Treat everything as important, even if it doesn't seem to have significance. You have a lot of opportunity to skip over the lore in this game (some conversation with Ida is optional, and you're not obligated to read any of the loose papers and articles around the hut), and unfortanately it can make the game's ending very confusing.

If you're the kind of person who needs everything narrated and explained to you, and you're not one to care for reading and discovering all these things on your own or trying to build the timeline from what pieces you're given, you're probably going to have a bad time with this game from a narrative perspective.

You'll probably find a lot of people giving reviews here saying that the game ends confusingly and abruptly. It kind of does I suppose, but don't think that it ends on a cliff hanger or leaves you without closure. If you weren't paying close attention to the conversations with Ida or the whole talk about certain sensations and certain characters, I can see how the ending would make absolutely no sense if you're lacking some context.

Not that there isn't a bunch of little stuff to speculate about-- there's certainly plenty of gaps for players to fill in, much the same way you see people filling in the timeline from a game like FNAF. I certainly wouldn't mind seeing a Game Theory video on this game, actually. :)
