I'd been looking forward to this for a long time since I first saw some of the development videos with the eagle and mechanical girl. On the plus side, it's beautiful to look at, and the soundtrack is very good too (and worth getting), and there's a lot of setting detail to explore.

Unfortunately though, while the final product is a valiant attempt, it's somewhat flawed:

For example - the background setting is pretty interesting, but it's somewhat incoherent. Concepts are introduced and then nothing is done with them. There's a lot of it scattered around the yurt that is your 'home base' but you don't really know which bits are important for the story and which aren't.

The four cube-puzzle mini-games also seem out of place and yanked me out of the atmosphere of the rest of the game somewhat. While they have an explanation in the plot, they're not really necessary to progress through the game (and fortunately you can skip them once you've played them once - but it would have been nicer to be able to skip them completely). Plus it gets a bit repetitive to have to keep going back to the Garden just to get more bits for Ida to continue the plot. Also, I thought the last game was pretty difficult to get to and particularly frustrating to play, which was really annoying.

The biggest problem though is the story itself. It just doesn't really hang together, and first time you see the ending I think there's a very good chance that you'll be saying What?! WTF just happened here?". There are clues whose locations in the yurt are revealed in the final video

reviewText:
Set in the Mongolian steppes about 60 years in the future, Cradle is a first-person adventure game with a rather unique premise. You wake up in a wonderfully detailed yurt that looks convincingly lived-in. Most of the worldbuilding in the game is concentrated in this tiny space, with dozens of newspaper clippings and foreign objects outlining a fascinating transhumanist future which has partially, but not completely, also arrived to this tent in the middle of nowhere.

Outside on the vast plains, a hovertram line stretches out to the horizon with precious few other landmarks besides a huge, abandoned dome of some sorts. It's up to you to puzzle out the story and the big picture by reading and observing things, but mostly by gathering parts to an old android in your possession.

Getting that thing to talk for the first time is a revelation in a game which had been very silent and tranquil up to that point. Unfortunately, at that time you will already have passed the best portions of the game. The first few hours of Cradle are as good as anything I've played, with a truly engaging world and lots of fresh ideas. Sure, you do run up against a rather jarring piece of videogame logic right in the first puzzle, but I was willing to forgive the game for that. However, it got much worse.

It's like the writers and designers eventually had no idea what to do with their creation. The story gets progressively less interesting when more and more details about it are revealed. reviewText:
First of all, this review is from the perspective of an avid FPS, RTS gamer that also likes racing games. I look for games that can give me about $0.50 or less per hour of entertainment. At $13, I was hoping to get maybe 20-25 hours or so out of it but I don't think I can last that long.

I was looking for a casual relaxing adventure game and Cradle caught my eye. After watching some game play on YouTube I decided to buy it. Fours hours in and I'm disappointed. It seems to get you into a grind, or misbehaves completely causing you to restart the game from a game defined save point.

Pros:
Great atmospherics, rich unique story line and really great music. This game has tremendous potential.

Cons:
The cube game. Tiring and doesn't enrich the overall story (that I could determine). I usually walk away and come back later to “skip” the game because I've lost and I get the game item anyhow.

Bad or inconsistent game physics. Picking things up and dropping/throwing them at times is tedious or difficult. I placed an item on the bed so I wouldn't have to look around on the floor for it. Wrong move. I could never pick up the item because the bed is selectable, all I could do was “sleep” when I tried to select the item on the bed. I had to restart the game and do a bunch of tedious things all over again.

Inventory. I believe an item was added to my inventory without my knowledge, but I can't be certain. Also, there is no callout on items, so you can pick up some technical thing and have no idea what it is. OK, maybe that's part of the game, but can add to the overall frustration.

Conclusion. Wonderful wonderful imagery, story line and music, and figuring out what to do in this “open world” is really fun. However basic game rules are inconsistent. Maybe this needs some really good QA. Not sure if this was early access with user feedback, if not, it should have been. Maybe this IS early access?

Finally: Watch some YouTube game play and if you don't mind some grind and rule bending by the game machine, you might really enjoy this.

Cheers

reviewText:
If you are looking for an unforgettable exploration/adventure game oozing with atmosphere and fascinating dark sci-fi concepts – you need to experience Cradle.

Cradle builds a superbly unique and colorful vision of the future. There's a drastic contrast between the rolling hills and meandering rivers of the steppe and the stark ruins of the “amusement park”, retro- futuristic mongolian yurt and hover train rings. There's something desolate, yet peaceful about the environment. The sweeping vistas are beautifully realized and the world feels lived in; by the end I was dying to see more.

The soundtrack is perfect for the setting and varies in flavor from relaxing eastern melodies to driving synth tracks amidst the more dramatic sequences.

I personally enjoyed the narrative but it seems the ending is one of the highly debated topics on the community forums. If you get confused, many plot elements are clarified via clues densely scattered around the environment so a thorough playthrough is definitely rewarded. There is also a continually evolving community discussion on plot line theories and meaning for reference after completing the game.

The only real complaint I have is that some of the mechanics can be slightly frustrating and repetitive, although, to the devs credit, they give an option to skip these sequences.

In the end, Cradle is one of those games that draws you in and before you know it, it's two in the morning. If you are a sci-fi or adventure game fan - it's well worth the cost just to experience Cradle's unique dystopian vision of the future. You won't regret it.

reviewText:
Cradle is an amalgam of different ideas that end up making the game less than the sum of its parts.

This game has some truly interesting thoughts on humanity's future and how people are valued, but these concepts are mixed in with a very ambiguous overall story that is conveyed almost entirely through notes and in-game art.  Even after analyzing most of those, the story is still very hard to make sense of.

The developers also went wrong in choosing to combine this confusing story with several cube/block based mini-games that you need to beat in order to advance the story.  They were frustrating and really hurt the pacing of the game; I wanted to keep exploring the story, not stopping to beat a level of frustrating gameplay every 30 minutes.

My advice to the developers: if you're going to make something story-based in a video game, you don't need to add in 'challenge' elements like a traditional game.  Make it more about experiencing the story, enjoying the art & environments, and connecting with the characters.

If you're looking for some great story-based gameplay that will leave you thinking about life instead of being frustrated and confused - go play SOMA or Firewatch.

Cradle is a wonderfully paced game with a compelling story that keeps you wanting to learn more as each layer of the mystery surrounding the characters is peeled away. Put that together with the beautiful and surreal setting and the gorgeous soundtrack, and you have a wonderfully enjoyable gaming experience.

I have one minor qualm: I found the overall play time a tad short. Having become so immersed in the world and the unfolding backstory of the characters and their places in that world, I felt a little sad to say goodbye. The story was all wrapped up very well at the end, but even so, it would have been nice to have had more time to enjoy it.

Having said that, I had so much fun with this game, and I really feel that we need more adventurous and quirky storytelling in games such as this. I would love to see more from these developers in the future. I'm probably going to replay some of the puzzle levels for a little while yet.

reviewText:
6/10 – Cool, but techically flawed
Cradle is a cool concept, first person exploration adventure-ish slightly puzzle-y narrative.  I like the abstract nature of the story, the environmental storytelling (shades of Gone Home), and the lack of hand-holding is a nice change from some in this genre.  There aren't really any mind-bending puzzles, but you do have to work out where things are that you need from time to time.  The game length is short but plenty long enough to get the concept across.  I look forward to more in-depth work from this crew in the future.

Preface: PC specs are i5-6600k, AMD Radeon Fury, SSD.  Strong machine.
The framerate bogs down to the 20s unless you have a controller plugged in.  What?  It crashed to desktop a a few times (4-5) in various areas.  Loading times are very slow.  After (re)loading a save, the framerate is choppy for about 30 seconds.  Much of the gameplay is a rinse and repeat pattern of going to do a rather dull minigame, retrieve an object, and take it home from a short narrative.   Lastly, the lead actor's voice acting is dull and seems uninterested.

This is a neat game worth a few bucks but more effort with polish in stability would present a more attractive package.

reviewText:
I have not had a great deal of experience with these ambient sort of games. Therefore, it should be understood that my experience is limited. I will, however, impart my review for those who are interested.

Cradle is ultimately a very unique and enjoyable game. I truly enjoyed many elements of the game:

The scenery is beautiful and fun to explore. But keep in mind that although the immediate area is seemingly immense, there are boundaries and very little interactive components.

The music is perhaps one of the most intriguing factors of the game. In this respect I'm glad that I purchased the soundtrack. The artwork that comes with the package is decent but nothing extraordinary.

The character design is also great although there are only a few characters. Ida is very compelling and I'm left wanting to know more about her. My gripe about the main character is his voice acting. I've read that his lack of intonation and inflexion was the director's intention. But it still comes across as flat and unauthentic which really took a while to get used to in the game (if I actually ever did).

So here is my final analysis:

The game was very enjoyable. I did enjoy the storyline, but unless you're prepared to read every scrap of paper you come across, and are willing to delve into a little deduction and theory, you may not enjoy the game. The storyline's denouement is not self-evident and rather cryptic.

The gripe that I do have about the storyline is that it ends just as it starts to become intriguing. I'm not so much opposed as to how the game ends as I am to when it ends. What actually seems like the beginning of a deeper storyline actually becomes the ending. The game had so much potential to be great by adding more content which would have inevitably provided a much richer storyline and experience for the player. I'm left wanting to play so much more knowing that it cannot happen.

For example ( SPOILER ):  I truly wanted to explore more of the game with Ida by completely fixing her to the point she could walk around with me.

I was also not so keen on the optional minigame which can be played a number of times as you advance through the game. I like challenges so I completed the minigame out of obligation. But I would've perfered that the developers spent more time extending the game rather than incorporating the minigame. But others may disagree with me on this point as it is relative to each person.

For the price the game is a good buy. I felt that I got my money's worth and really did enjoy the game. But it does have its issues which deprives Cradle from being phenomenal. Nevertheless, I recommned this game.
